message.content: Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work. They mention that the FedPop model does not allow for training heterogeneous architectures across clients due to the introduced common prior, and that it only satisfies first-order privacy guarantees. They also suggest directions for future work, such as deriving differentially private versions of their framework.

Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work. They specifically mention that FedPop does not allow for training heterogeneous architectures across clients due to the common prior and only satisfy first-order privacy guarantees. They also suggest areas for further research, such as deriving differentially private versions of their framework.

Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work. They mention that their model, FedPop, does not allow for training heterogeneous architectures across clients due to the introduced common prior, and it only satisfies first-order privacy guarantees. The authors also suggest further works like deriving differentially private versions of their framework to address these limitations.
